Iโm continuing to read the book โGreater Zhezkazganโ and would like to share my first impressions.
Due to its impressive volume, I havenโt finished it yet, but I can already see how deeply it explores the history of industrial development and the great role of Kanysh Satpayev.

I especially enjoy recalling my own trips to the region, where Iโve visited Ulytau many times โ a place that holds a special status among geologists.
You can literally feel the breath of the earth there, and the rocks seem to preserve entire epochs.

This book doesnโt just provide facts; it immerses the reader in the atmosphere of those times when Kazakhstanโs mining industry was just beginning to gain momentum.

Iโm confident that โGreater Zhezkazganโ will be of interest to everyone who wants to understand more about our shared heritage and the proud history of our homeland.

Special thanks to @kazakhmys_official for the opportunity to get acquainted with this monumental work, and to my colleagues @NuriyevNurakhmet and @SakenShayakhmetov for inspiring me to start reading and share my thoughts.

Even now I can say that this book opens new horizons in understanding how important and difficult the task was for the first geologists and workers who laid the foundation of the Zhezkazgan Mining and Metallurgical Complex.

Having read several chapters, I realize that such works not only help us reflect on past events but also teach us to appreciate the contribution of everyone who was involved in the development of the region.

I hope to finish the book very soon, but for now, I continue to enjoy every page, immersing myself in the unique atmosphere of those years.

content.en: Since ancient times, people have sought objects endowed with special powersโartifacts granted by the Divine. These artifacts were not merely things: each of them was a quintessence of humanityโs hopes and fears, a material embodiment of sacred archetypes. In myths, they served as shields against chaos or keys to forbidden knowledge, though often also sources of misfortune. Every sacred object contains a paradox: the power that can elevate the soul can also destroy it. To carry the 'divine spark' means bearing the burden of responsibility, for it is not always clear whether a great achievement will justify the consequences blindly following in its wake. This contradiction is the very mystery of artifacts. They bind legends together, becoming the central thread of the storyโbe it a holy grail that grants immortality or a blade that alters the fate of kingdoms. Around them always forms the 'myth of power': the most worthy wields the artifactโor the artifact itself chooses its bearer. In many legends, the hero, upon finding a relic, sacrifices part of themselves to gain a 'higher' power and only later understands the true cost of the deal. The sacred greatness of such objects comes not only from their miraculous properties but from peopleโs readiness to believe in them. Something deep within the soul yearns for a material symbol of cherished dreams or prayers. A gaze cast upon a relic awakens aweโwhether it stems from ancient memories of secret rituals or the quiet voice of hope that not everything in this world is random. Yet the true essence of artifacts lies not in their outward brilliance or legendary aura, but in how they guide us through inner trials. They test our virtue and compassion. Perhaps this is why every sacred item is often accompanied by a 'curse'โas if existence itself warns that every drop of wonder carries a drop of danger. And perhaps the main lesson is not in mastering the artifact, but in learning to hold it with caution in the heart. For sacredness is the finest line between destruction and transformation. The true purpose of a relic is to give a person the chance to accept both their darkness and light, to learn not to lose their humanityโeven when touching the 'beyond.' In the end, every such object is just a mirror, showing what we hide inside: lust for power, fear of loneliness, hope for redemption, or immortal inspiration. And if we can look into this mirror without self-deception, perhaps we will find not just a miracle, but a quiet understanding of the eternal, mystical connection between world and spirit. So it is with rare earth metals: one who seeks to master them invites a new source of power into their existenceโone that carries unforeseen consequences. The one who dares to wield them must balance the thirst for progress with the fear of becoming hostage to their own ambition. And for one who seeks to become a leader in the industry of these 'metamodern artifacts,' more than willpower and perseverance is required. They must have the capacity for deep self-reflection, to recognize the temptations of power and remain true to their core values. They must find the courage to combine clarity of mind with sensitivity to the world, so that the power they wield does not turn into their inner shadow, but becomes a foundation for meaningful and responsible creation.

content.en: At the initiative of the Committee of Geology of the Ministry of Industry and Infrastructure Development of the Republic of Kazakhstan, an important event was held at the Satbayev Institute of Geological Sciences (part of Satbayev University) โ the 75th anniversary of the outstanding scientist and statesman Serikbek Zhussupbekovich Daukeev, whose name is closely linked to the development of geological science and the industry in Kazakhstan. What makes this event special is that it was made possible thanks to the proposal of the Chairman of the Committee, Yerlan Yesenalievich Akbarov, to hold the celebration at our institute. This was not only an act of respect for Mr. Daukeev but also a symbolic recognition of our instituteโs contribution to geological science. Thanks to this initiative, we were able to gather at this meaningful place to congratulate the celebrant and once again highlight the value of science, education, and those who drive geological progress in Kazakhstan. Serikbek Zhussupbekovich is a person who not only led key government institutions but also became a symbol of stability and progress in the geological field. His work as Minister of Geology, Chairman of the Committee, and Director of our institute left an indelible mark in history. We are proud that this day became part of our instituteโs story, and we thank the Committee for the support and opportunity to host this ceremony here! The Chairman of the Committee read aloud the congratulations and warm wishes of the Head of State, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, addressed to our honoree. าาฑัะผะตััั ะกะตััะบะฑะตะบ ะาฏััะฟะฑะตะบาฑะปั, today is a great honor for us all! content.en: Today, our Satbayev Institute of Geological Sciences was honored to welcome Shafag Bayramova, Head of the Paleontology and Stratigraphy Division of the Institute of Geology and Geophysics under the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Azerbaijan. During her working visit, Shafag Bayramova met with her Kazakhstani colleaguesโpaleontologists and stratigraphersโand in a warm, friendly and professional atmosphere, they discussed key areas of cooperation that could elevate geological science in both countries: ๐น Exchange of experience between scientific schools of Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan โ strengthening international ties. ๐น Mineral exploration and extraction โ sharing advanced methodologies and technologies. ๐น Geophysical and geochemical research โ joint projects to study subsurface structures. ๐น Energy security and sustainable resource development โ balancing extraction and ecology. ๐น Training of young specialists and joint expeditions โ forming a new generation of geologists. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan are connected not only by shared history but also by a strategic vision for the development of geology, the oil and gas sector, and mineral resources. I am confident this is just the beginning of a long-term and fruitful partnership!

content.en: Today, our Satbayev Institute of Geological Sciences, together with Esentai Gallery, held a unique event โ 'The Geological Foundation of the World.' As part of the exhibition of artist Ekaterina Nikonorova, an engaging lecture was given by Dr. Saida Nigmatova, head of the Mesozoic and Cenozoic research lab and doctor of geological and mineralogical sciences. Art lovers and those eager to understand our planet's history came together in one space. The result was a genuine synthesis of Earth sciences and creative perception. Why do this? We believe in the harmony of nature and humanity, science and art. Geology can help artists see the world through millions of years of history, and art brings new aesthetics into scientific perception. For our institute, this is an important step: we aim to show that fundamental knowledge about the processes that formed the Earth can be not only scientifically valuable but also inspiring for the general public. Such steps can truly inspire young talent โ the same principles followed by Kanysh Satpayev and Mukhtar Auezov in their long-standing friendship and creative collaboration. I sincerely hope this evening is just the beginning of a broader dialogue between science and creativity. When we combine knowledge of nature with artistic interpretation, something greater is born โ a new language through which the world can speak.
